items.title: City Housing Projects Call For Environmental Help
items.abstract: Housing project residents say the city encouraged them to “go green,” but did little to help them and in some circumstances, stood in their way.

items.title: Ada Louise Huxtable, Champion of Livable Architecture, Dies at 91
items.abstract: Ms. Huxtable pioneered modern architectural criticism in The New York Times, celebrating buildings that respected human dignity and civic history.

items.title: In Rural Minnesota, a 70-Acre Lab for Sustainable Living
items.abstract: Imagine a house that can go without heating for two days in a bitterly cold winter. Or a greenhouse with what may be the largest hot-air solar panel array in North America.

items.title: Wild’s Big Signings Reinvigorate a ‘Hockey-Crazy City’
items.abstract: Declining attendance and lackluster play prompted the Wild owner to lavish identical 13-year, $98 million contracts on the high-profile free agents Zach Parise and Ryan Suter.

items.title: Edward I. Koch, a Mayor as Brash, Shrewd and Colorful as the City He Led, Dies at 88
items.abstract: Mr. Koch, a showman of City Hall, was a three-term mayor who steered New York City through the fiscal austerity of the late 1970s and the racial conflicts of the 1980s.

items.title: De Blasio Names Herminia Palacio as Deputy Mayor for Health and Human Services
items.abstract: The appointment of Dr. Palacio, 54 and a native of the Bronx, fills a key role in the city’s efforts to confront a rise in homelessness.

items.title: State Challenges Plan to Revive City Opera
items.abstract: In a filing in federal bankrupcty court, the New York State Attorney General’s office raises several questions about a proposed reorganization of the defunct opera company.

items.title: On the Stockholm Waterfront, ‘Renewing a New City’
items.abstract: Sustainable housing plans have transformed Hammarby Sjostad, a neighborhood in Stockholm. Now, new cultural projects are providing another boost.

items.title: MoMA PS1 Names Winner of Summer Architecture Competition
items.abstract: Escobedo Solíz Studio, a partnership based in Mexico City, will transform the museum’s courtyard this summer.

items.title: Vancouver Explores Its First Nations Roots
items.abstract: Beyond the totem poles long displayed in Stanley Park, visitors to Vancouver can now gain a fuller appreciation for the area’s native people.

items.title: Students in Rural America Ask, ‘What Is a University Without a History Major?’
items.abstract: Financial and enrollment woes at schools like the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point have led to a scramble for fixes, such as dropping longstanding liberal arts degrees.

items.title: To Save East River Park, the City Intends to Bury It
items.abstract: A plan to protect the Lower East Side from flooding was just rejected by the city, replaced with a drastic revision that costs twice as much but does not disrupt traffic.

items.title: A Guide to Antigua, Guatemala: A Candy-Colored City Framed by Volcanoes
items.abstract: With its Baroque architecture and thriving textile scene, this former colonial capital is among Central America’s most beguiling destinations.

items.title: A Growing Chorus of Big City Prosecutors Say No to Marijuana Convictions
items.abstract: Marlyn Mosby, Baltimore’s top prosecutor, says she will no longer prosecute marijuana possession cases and will vacate thousands of convictions. The police disagree.

items.title: Review: At City Ballet, More Youthful Invention From Justin Peck
items.abstract: Justin Peck’s new “Principia” is imaginative, friendly, and wistful — like many of his previous dances.

items.title: Nashville Finds Opportunity in the Hole a Bomber Left in the Heart of the City
items.abstract: Since the explosion last Christmas, the city has grappled with how rebuilding will fit into its larger ambitions of transforming downtown. The hope is to draw more than just tourists.

items.title: A Rising Designer Brings Hip-Hop to Homeware
items.abstract: Sean Brown is the creative force behind Curves, a home décor brand inspired by African American pop culture. “I always aim to celebrate Blackness,” he said.

items.title: When Production Design Plays a Supporting Role
items.abstract: The visual environments of “West Side Story,” “The Humans” and “Nightmare Alley” feel as alive as the actors.

items.title: America’s Most Energy Efficient Cities
items.abstract: A new report by the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy can help you gauge just how green your city is — or wants to be.

items.title: New Virus Cases Begin to Slow in U.S. Cities Where Omicron Hit First
items.abstract: Reports of infections are falling in Cleveland, Newark and Washington, suggesting that a national peak may be approaching.
